awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Developing modular repressors as in vivo biosensors in various organisms
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall goal of this research is to establish an approach to construct new biological components that would advance the understanding of novel cellular behavior for practical applications. At this point in time, scientists are capable of designing complex genetic networks to generate desirable biological behavior. However, the implementation of many network designs is hampered by the lack of modular components to build flexible and rewireable connections between different parts of genetic networks. In this project, the research team is establishing a design principle for generating modular chemical sensors within various organisms. These sensors build new linkages between environmental signals and gene expression regulation. The design principle is used to develop biosafety devices in various organisms, enhancing the safety levels of using these organisms in industrial and clinical settings. Products of this project will facilitate the creation of genetically modified organisms in many biotechnology industries. This project also provides opportunities for undergraduate student training in synthetic biology at the University of Texas at Tyler. An undergraduate team is established to join an international synthetic biology competition (iGEM), in which participants will develop engineered biological entities to solve problems involving genetic engineering. Outreach activities to  promote synthetic biology among K-12 students are also planned. 

The research team is implementing a range of scientific approaches, including protein structure analysis, bioinformatics, computational modeling, and in vivo transcription assay, in identifying DNA-binding modules and allosteric response modules in different repressor families, such as LacI and TetR. These modules are mixed and matched to generate resulting hybrid repressors that possess novel combinations of signal detection and DNA operator recognition properties. These recognition properties are harnessed to build new cellular response pathways in genetic circuits for creating novel cellular behavior. Specifically, the research team is using these hybrid repressors to establish a biocontainment platform that can be implemented in various organisms. The engineered organisms are constrained to survive only in a highly specific condition.

por.por_cntn:
Synthetic biology is a field of science that involves altering organisms for valuable purposes by engineering them to have new abilities. Within synthetic biology, one of the primary goals is to program genetic response behavior to biological and chemical cues in a wide range of biological systems. In alternative pathways between signal detection and cellular response, synthetic biologists have engineered various biological components that enable the use of multiple molecular signals to control the activity of a specific DNA-based promoter for driving gene expression. The design of modular parts for a targeted purpose helps to develop genetic circuits in specific biological systems. Many modular receptors mentioned above are membrane-bound proteins, which constrains their use in cells with different membrane architectures. 

Additionally, these sensors detect signals relevant to particular physiological conditions, such as unique antigens or cell-cell interactions. These modular parts are ideal for their intended applications but might not apply to new hosts under different environments. Building a genetic circuit in a new cell type usually requires extensive searching and engineering of circuit parts. However, modular sensors function universally in various organisms to wire molecular inputs and phenotype outputs would be a significant step forward.

Through the scheme of hybrid transcriptional regulators as modular genetic sensors for novel wiring amongst input signals and genetic elements to control outputs. The members of numerous allosterically synchronized regulator families contain structurally conserved and functionally independent protein domains, including a DNA-binding module for interacting with a specific genetic element and a ligand-binding module for sensing an input signal. A hybrid regulator can be created with a new combination of signal detection and DNA-recognition properties not present in natural systems. Our work expands the development of modular sensors to transcriptional regulators in the TetR family. TetR is a well-characterized regulator used extensively to construct genetic circuits. We use a DNA-binding module from TetR and a ligand-binding module from MphR to build a TetR-MphR hybrid regulator with desirable properties, in which the engineered regulator binds to the DNA sequence recognized by TetR and responds to the inducer of MphR. By demonstrating that TetR family regulators are competent for generating modular sensors, our work will facilitate the creation of biological circuit components for cell engineering (Figure 1, Modular Gene Expression Response). Through domain swapping, the DNA-binding domain from one regulator is strategically combined with the signal detection domain from another regulator to create a compelling hybrid regulator. This hybrid unambiguously binds to the regulator's DNA operator while simultaneously responding to the regulator's inducer (Figure 1). Our work reveals that the module-swapping strategy is feasible for regulators in the TetR family. We can use a similar coevolutionary modeling approach to identify TetR family members compatible with constructing hybrid regulators. We are well on our long-term goal of creating biomolecular components for developing new behaviors in biological systems. Our work may be helpful for cell engineering in many biotechnology industries, generating positive impacts on both economic and societal levels. This project provided opportunities to students at the University of Texas at Tyler (UT Tyler) in the field of synthetic biology.
